oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Team of oxen
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A man with a hat stands next to a team of oxen. A river and a steamboat can be seen in the background. The man is standing near some wooden structures, one of which may be a barn. The name of the steamboat is the "City of Memphis."

Oxen were the predominant work animal in the American South up to the late nineteenth century. Yoked oxen were well-suited for heavy loads - perfect for lifting heavy wagons up muddy river landings. Oxen were heavy-duty, strong, but slow animals. Prior to mules, oxen were often used in agricultural labor. The fact that these workers were still using oxen ca. 1900 is significant.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Steamboats; Ox teams; Laborers; Rivers; Farming; Bodies of water
